restapi.shapefile package¶

Module contents¶

shapefile.py Provides read and write support for ESRI Shapefiles. author: jlawhead<at>geospatialpython.com date: 2015/06/22 version: 1.2.3 Compatible with Python versions 2.4-3.x version changelog: Reader.iterShapeRecords() bugfix for Python 3

class restapi.shapefile.Editor(shapefile=None, shapeType=1, autoBalance=1)[source]¶

Bases: restapi.shapefile.Writer

balance()[source]¶

Adds a corresponding empty attribute or null geometry record depending on which type of record was created to make sure all three files are in synch.

delete(shape=None, part=None, point=None)[source]¶

Deletes the specified part of any shape by specifying a shape number, part number, or point number.

point(x=None, y=None, z=None, m=None, shape=None, part=None, point=None, addr=None)[source]¶

Creates/updates a point shape. The arguments allows you to update a specific point by shape, part, point of any shape type.

select(expr)[source]¶

Select one or more shapes (to be implemented)

validate()[source]¶

An optional method to try and validate the shapefile as much as possible before writing it (not implemented).

class restapi.shapefile.Reader(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

Reads the three files of a shapefile as a unit or separately. If one of the three files (.shp, .shx, .dbf) is missing no exception is thrown until you try to call a method that depends on that particular file. The .shx index file is used if available for efficiency but is not required to read the geometry from the .shp file. The “shapefile” argument in the constructor is the name of the file you want to open. You can instantiate a Reader without specifying a shapefile and then specify one later with the load() method. Only the shapefile headers are read upon loading. Content within each file is only accessed when required and as efficiently as possible. Shapefiles are usually not large but they can be.

iterRecords()[source]¶

Serves up records in a dbf file as an iterator. Useful for large shapefiles or dbf files.

iterShapeRecords()[source]¶

Returns a generator of combination geometry/attribute records for all records in a shapefile.

iterShapes()[source]¶

Serves up shapes in a shapefile as an iterator. Useful for handling large shapefiles.

load(shapefile=None)[source]¶

Opens a shapefile from a filename or file-like object. Normally this method would be called by the constructor with the file object or file name as an argument.

record(i=0)[source]¶

Returns a specific dbf record based on the supplied index.

records()[source]¶

Returns all records in a dbf file.

shape(i=0)[source]¶

Returns a shape object for a shape in the the geometry record file.

shapeRecord(i=0)[source]¶

Returns a combination geometry and attribute record for the supplied record index.

shapeRecords()[source]¶

Returns a list of combination geometry/attribute records for all records in a shapefile.

shapes()[source]¶

Returns all shapes in a shapefile.

exception restapi.shapefile.ShapefileException[source]¶

Bases: Exception

An exception to handle shapefile specific problems.

class restapi.shapefile.Writer(shapeType=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Provides write support for ESRI Shapefiles.

bbox()[source]¶

Returns the current bounding box for the shapefile which is the lower-left and upper-right corners. It does not contain the elevation or measure extremes.

field(name, fieldType='C', size='50', decimal=0)[source]¶

Adds a dbf field descriptor to the shapefile.

line(parts=[], shapeType=3)[source]¶

Creates a line shape. This method is just a convienience method which wraps ‘poly()’.

mbox()[source]¶

Returns the current m extremes for the shapefile.

null()[source]¶

Creates a null shape.

point(x, y, z=0, m=0)[source]¶

Creates a point shape.

poly(parts=[], shapeType=5, partTypes=[])[source]¶

Creates a shape that has multiple collections of points (parts) including lines, polygons, and even multipoint shapes. If no shape type is specified it defaults to ‘polygon’. If no part types are specified (which they normally won’t be) then all parts default to the shape type.

record(*recordList, **recordDict)[source]¶

Creates a dbf attribute record. You can submit either a sequence of field values or keyword arguments of field names and values. Before adding records you must add fields for the record values using the fields() method. If the record values exceed the number of fields the extra ones won’t be added. In the case of using keyword arguments to specify field/value pairs only fields matching the already registered fields will be added.

save(target=None, shp=None, shx=None, dbf=None)[source]¶

Save the shapefile data to three files or three file-like objects. SHP and DBF files can also be written exclusively using saveShp, saveShx, and saveDbf respectively. If target is specified but not shp,shx, or dbf then the target path and file name are used. If no options or specified, a unique base file name is generated to save the files and the base file name is returned as a string.

saveDbf(target)[source]¶

Save a dbf file.

saveShp(target)[source]¶

Save an shp file.

saveShx(target)[source]¶

Save an shx file.

Returns the current z extremes for the shapefile.

restapi.shapefile.b(v)[source]¶
restapi.shapefile.is_string(v)[source]¶
restapi.shapefile.signed_area(coords)[source]¶

Return the signed area enclosed by a ring using the linear time algorithm at http://www.cgafaq.info/wiki/Polygon_Area. A value >= 0 indicates a counter-clockwise oriented ring.
